# Summary bar graphs {.unnumbered} :::: {.callout-note collapse="false" icon=false} ::: {style="font-size: 1.25em; color: #02577A;"} Graph info :::
::: {.cell layout-align="right"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](sum_bar_graphs_files/figure-html/full_code_display-1.png){fig-align='right' width=60% height=60%} ::: ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #02577A;"} **This graph requires:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.05em; color: #282b2d;"} **✅ a numeric (continuous) variable** **✅ a categorical variable** ::: :::: ## Description Summary bar graphs display the sum (or total) of a numerical variable across the levels of a second categorical variable. Color is used to make comparisons and distinguish between groups (or levels) of the categorical variable. In `ggplot2`, we can create summary bar graphs with `geom_bar()`. ## Getting set up :::: {.panel-tabset} ### Packages ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **PACKAGES:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} Install packages. ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} install.packages("palmerpenguins") library(palmerpenguins) library(ggplot2) ``` ::: ::: ### Data ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **DATA:** ::: ::: {.column-margin} ![Artwork by Allison Horst](www/lter_penguins.png){fig-align="right" width="100%" height="100%"} ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} Remove the missing values from `body_mass_g` and `island` in the `palmerpenguins::penguins` data and convert body mass in grams to kilograms (`body_mass_kg`). *We'll also reduce the number of columns in the `penguins` data for clarity.* ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} peng_sum_col <- palmerpenguins::penguins |> dplyr::select(body_mass_g, island) |> tidyr::drop_na() |> # divide the mass value by 1000 dplyr::mutate( body_mass_kg = body_mass_g / 1000 ) dplyr::glimpse(peng_sum_col) #> Rows: 342 #> Columns: 3 #> $ body_mass_g 3750, 3800, 3250, 3450, 3650, 3625, 4… #> $ island Torgersen, Torgersen, Torgersen, Torg… #> $ body_mass_kg 3.750, 3.800, 3.250, 3.450, 3.650, 3.… ``` ::: ::: :::: ## The grammar :::: {.panel-tabset} ### Code ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **CODE:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} Create labels with `labs()` Initialize the graph with `ggplot()` and provide `data` Map `island` to `x` and `body_mass_kg` to `y` *Inside* the `aes()` of `geom_col()`, map `island` to `fill` *Outside* the `aes()` of `geom_col()`, remove the legend with `show.legend = FALSE` ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} labs_sum_col <- labs( title = "Total Penguin Mass", subtitle = "How many kilograms of penguin per Island?", x = "Island", y = "Total Penguin Body Mass (kg)") ggp2_sum_col <- ggplot(data = peng_sum_col, aes(x = island, y = body_mass_kg)) + geom_col(aes(fill = island), show.legend = FALSE) ggp2_sum_col + labs_sum_col ``` ::: ::: ### Graph ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **GRAPH:** ::: ::: {.cell .column-page-inset-right layout-nrow="1"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](sum_bar_graphs_files/figure-html/create_graph_sum_col-1.png){width=100% height=100%} ::: ::: :::: ## More Info Note that we didn't have to write any code to calculate the total `body_mass_g` (displayed on the `y` axis) by `island`. That's because `ggplot2` does this for us! :::: {.panel-tabset} ### Summary ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **SUMMARY:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} If we pass a categorical variable to the `x` (like `island`) and a continuous variable to `y` (like `body_mass_kg`), `geom_col()` will calculate the `sum()` of `y` by levels of `x` ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} We can see the underlying summary of budget using `dplyr`’s `group_by()` and `summarise()` functions. ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} palmerpenguins::penguins |> dplyr::select(body_mass_g, island) |> tidyr::drop_na() |> # divide the mass value by 1000 dplyr::mutate( body_mass_kg = body_mass_g / 1000 ) |> dplyr::group_by(island) |> dplyr::summarise( `Total Penguin Body Mass (kg)` = sum(body_mass_kg)) |> dplyr::ungroup() |> dplyr::select(`Island` = island, `Total Penguin Body Mass (kg)`) ``` ::: ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell .column-page-inset-right layout-nrow="1"} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Island Total Penguin Body Mass (kg)
Biscoe 787.575
Dream 460.400
Torgersen 189.025
````` ::: ::: ::: ### Identity vs. Count ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **STATS:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} The `geom_bar()` geom will also create grouped bar graphs, but we have to switch the `stat` argument to `"identity"`. ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell .column-page-inset-right layout-nrow="1"} ```{.r .cell-code} ggplot(data = peng_sum_col, aes(x = island, y = body_mass_kg)) + geom_col(aes(fill = island), show.legend = FALSE, stat = "identity") + labs_sum_col ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](sum_bar_graphs_files/figure-html/show_stat_sum_col-1.png){width=100% height=100%} ::: ::: ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **`geom_bar()` vs. `geom_col()`:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} `geom_bar()` will map a categorical variable to the `x` *or* `y` and display counts for the discrete levels (see [`stat_count()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/geom_bar.html) for more info) `geom_col()` will map *both* `x` *and* `y` aesthetics, and is used when we want to display numerical (quantitative) values across the levels of a categorical variable. `geom_col()` assumes these values have been created in their own column (see [`stat_identity()`](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/reference/stat_identity.html) for more info) ::: ::::
